segment.source: This topic contains a brief overview of the accounts and groups, log files, and other security-related considerations for Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM).
segment.target: This topic contains a brief overview of the accounts and groups, log files, and other security-related considerations for Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM).

segment.source: For more information, follow the links in this article.
segment.target: For more information, follow the links in this article.

segment.source: General security considerations
segment.target: General security considerations

segment.source: Understand the security risks.
segment.target: Understand the security risks.

segment.source: The most serious risk to MBAM is that its functionality could be hijacked by an unauthorized user who could then reconfigure BitLocker encryption and gain BitLocker encryption key data on MBAM Clients.
segment.target: The most serious risk to MBAM is that its functionality could be hijacked by an unauthorized user who could then reconfigure BitLocker encryption and gain BitLocker encryption key data on MBAM Clients.

segment.source: However, the loss of MBAM functionality for a short period of time due to a denial-of-service attack would not generally have a catastrophic impact.
segment.target: However, the loss of MBAM functionality for a short period of time due to a denial-of-service attack would not generally have a catastrophic impact.

segment.source: Physically secure your computers.
segment.target: Physically secure your computers.

segment.source: Security is incomplete without physical security.
segment.target: Security is incomplete without physical security.

segment.source: Anyone with physical access to an MBAM Server could potentially attack the entire client base.
segment.target: Anyone with physical access to an MBAM Server could potentially attack the entire client base.

segment.source: Any potential physical attacks must be considered high risk and mitigated appropriately.
segment.target: Any potential physical attacks must be considered high risk and mitigated appropriately.

segment.source: MBAM servers should be stored in a physically secure server room with controlled access.
segment.target: MBAM servers should be stored in a physically secure server room with controlled access.

segment.source: Secure these computers when administrators are not physically present by having the operating system lock the computer, or by using a secured screen saver.
segment.target: Secure these computers when administrators are not physically present by having the operating system lock the computer, or by using a secured screen saver.

segment.source: Apply the most recent security updates to all computers.
segment.target: Apply the most recent security updates to all computers.

segment.source: Stay informed about new updates for operating systems, Microsoft SQL Server, and MBAM by subscribing to the Security Notification service (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=28819).
segment.target: Stay informed about new updates for operating systems, Microsoft SQL Server, and MBAM by subscribing to the Security Notification service (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=28819).

segment.source: Use strong passwords or pass phrases.
segment.target: Use strong passwords or pass phrases.

segment.source: Always use strong passwords with 15 or more characters for all MBAM and MBAM administrator accounts.
segment.target: Always use strong passwords with 15 or more characters for all MBAM and MBAM administrator accounts.

segment.source: Never use blank passwords.
segment.target: Never use blank passwords.

segment.source: For more information about password concepts, see the “Account Passwords and Policies” white paper on TechNet (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=30009).
segment.target: For more information about password concepts, see the “Account Passwords and Policies” white paper on TechNet (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=30009).

segment.target: Accounts and Groups in MBAM

segment.source: A best practice for user account management is to create domain global groups and add user accounts to them.

segment.source: Then, add the domain global accounts to the necessary MBAM local groups on the MBAM Servers.

segment.source: MBAM Database TDE considerations
segment.target: MBAM Database TDE considerations

segment.source: The Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) feature available in SQL Server 2008 is a required installation prerequisite for the database instances that will host MBAM database features.
segment.target: The Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) feature available in SQL Server 2008 is a required installation prerequisite for the database instances that will host MBAM database features.

segment.source: With TDE, you can perform real-time, full database-level encryption.
segment.target: With TDE, you can perform real-time, full database-level encryption.

segment.source: TDE is a well-suited choice for bulk encryption to meet regulatory compliance or corporate data security standards.
segment.target: TDE is a well-suited choice for bulk encryption to meet regulatory compliance or corporate data security standards.

segment.source: TDE works at the file level, which is similar to two Windows features: the Encrypting File System (EFS) and BitLocker Drive Encryption, both of which also encrypt data on the hard drive.
segment.target: TDE works at the file level, which is similar to two Windows features: the Encrypting File System (EFS) and BitLocker Drive Encryption, both of which also encrypt data on the hard drive.

segment.source: TDE does not replace cell-level encryption, EFS, or BitLocker.
segment.target: TDE does not replace cell-level encryption, EFS, or BitLocker.

segment.source: When TDE is enabled on a database, all backups are encrypted.
segment.target: When TDE is enabled on a database, all backups are encrypted.

segment.source: Thus, special care must be taken to ensure that the certificate that was used to protect the Database Encryption Key (DEK) is backed up and maintained with the database backup.
segment.target: Thus, special care must be taken to ensure that the certificate that was used to protect the Database Encryption Key (DEK) is backed up and maintained with the database backup.

segment.source: Without a certificate, the data will be unreadable.
segment.target: Without a certificate, the data will be unreadable.

segment.source: Back up the certificate along with the database.
segment.target: Back up the certificate along with the database.

segment.source: Each certificate backup should have two files; both of these files should be archived .It is best to archive them separately from the database backup file for security.
segment.target: Each certificate backup should have two files; both of these files should be archived .It is best to archive them separately from the database backup file for security.

segment.source: For an example of how to enable TDE for MBAM database instances, see Evaluating MBAM 1.0.
segment.target: For an example of how to enable TDE for MBAM database instances, see Evaluating MBAM 1.0.

segment.source: For more information about TDE in SQL Server 2008, see Database Encryption in SQL Server 2008 Enterprise Edition.
segment.target: For more information about TDE in SQL Server 2008, see Database Encryption in SQL Server 2008 Enterprise Edition.
